sections.title: Adapting to Life's Transitions
sections.subtitle: Adjusting your budget for major life events and changes

sections.title: What You'll Learn
items: Common life changes that affect budgeting

sections.title: Predictable Life Changes
sections.content: Many life changes are predictable and can be planned for in advance. Marriage, having children, buying a home, or retirement all have significant budget impacts. Start planning for these transitions 1-2 years in advance when possible.

points.title: Career Changes
points.description: Job loss, promotion, or career switch - update income projections and adjust expenses accordingly.

points.title: Family Changes
points.description: Marriage, divorce, or children - significant impacts on housing, insurance, and daily expenses.

points.title: Housing Changes
points.description: Moving, buying a home, or downsizing - major changes to housing costs and one-time expenses.

sections.title: Build Flexibility into Your Budget
sections.content: Life is unpredictable. Include buffers for unexpected expenses and be prepared to adjust your budget quickly when circumstances change.

sections.title: Emergency Budgeting
sections.content: For unexpected changes like job loss or major repairs, have a contingency plan. This might include cutting non-essential expenses, using emergency funds, or finding additional income sources. Focus on essential expenses first and look for temporary cost-saving measures.

sections.title: Prepare for Life Changes
steps: Identify potential life changes in the next 1-3 years
Estimate the financial impact of each potential change
Build flexibility into your current budget
Create contingency plans for unexpected changes

sections.title: Communicate About Money
sections.content: Major life changes often involve other people. Discuss financial expectations and plans openly with partners, family members, or others affected by the change.
